title: Why do I have an IEP if I have no disabilities? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to the PL 94–142 you MUST have a disability to have an IEP. An IEP is an Individualized Educational Plan. To qualify for one you must have undergone extensive screenings, which are then gone over by the school and your parents. If there is an area of concern, a diagnostic plan is formulated and your parents would have had to sign for you to have been tested. Once all testing is completed your parents and the school officials would gather back and discuss the findings, this would be the diagnostic summary. Based on the summary, if there was an area of concern that qualified you to have met criteria for service and IEP would have been compiled. If this is not what occurred, then you may simply have a 504 Accommodation Plan. You can have an Accommodation Plan for many things. You can be said to have a disabling condition by having a broken foot, by having a broken…anything that limits you in a life activity. I have written them for pregnant students. It would be very wise for your parents to seek assistance in this matter. They should have been given and briefed on their Parental Rights before any testing was done. A school may do screenings, but to completely single you out for testing is not appropriate. I can provide more information if you need it.

Have you asked your counselor or parents what your IEP is for? You may not have clear-cut signs of a “disability” but for some reason you have an IEP. Which could be very helpful for you. You need to find out why you have an IEP. Usually students know. You have the right to find out. Then you can center your learning more easily. There are many reasons why an IEP is written for a student. Sometimes a disability is not clear-cut, nor is it a disability at all—so yes, do ask. You need to know.
